elements.content: The structure transformation of a metal–organic framework (MOF) constructed by a pyrene-based ligand 1,3,6,8-tetrakis­(3,5-isophthalic acid)­pyrene (H 8 TIAPy), [Zn4(TIAPy)­·(DMSO)2­·(H2O)4]­·(Guest) (JUC-118), was investigated when soaked in different solvents. Single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that JUC-118 could convert into JUC-118-1, whose lattice parameters were obviously different in ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME). It was found that the torsion angles between the pyrene and the benenze rings of the ligand changed from 41.2 deg to 61.3 deg. Thus, the channel structure in the direction [101] had an obvious difference from a compressed rhombic shape to an expanded one. In addition, EGME could also induce complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II) when soaking either JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 in EGME. However, no similar phenomena were found while soaking them in DMF. As the lattice parameters changed, the fluorescence had a blue shift, from 485 to 460 nm. These observations might guide us to design and synthesize materials with a fluorescence response for guest recognition.
elements.clean_text: The structure transformation of a metal-organic framework (MOF) constructed by a pyrene-based ligand 1,3,6,8-tetrakis(3,5-isophthalic acid)pyrene (H  8  TIAPy), [Zn4(TIAPy)⋅(DMSO)2⋅(H2O)4]⋅(Guest) (JUC-118), was investigated when soaked in different solvents. Single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that JUC-118 could convert into JUC-118-1, whose lattice parameters were obviously different in ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME). It was found that the torsion angles between the pyrene and the benenze rings of the ligand changed from 41.2 deg to 61.3 deg. Thus, the channel structure in the direction [101] had an obvious difference from a compressed rhombic shape to an expanded one. In addition, EGME could also induce complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II) when soaking either JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 in EGME. However, no similar phenomena were found while soaking them in DMF. As the lattice parameters changed, the fluorescence had a blue shift, from 485 to 460 nm. These observations might guide us to design and synthesize materials with a fluorescence response for guest recognition.

elements.content: Solvent-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation of [Zn4(TIAPy)­·(DMSO)2­·(H2O)4]­·(Guest) (JUC-118) occurs in ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME), caused by the change of the dihedral angle between the pyrene and benzene rings in the ligand. In addition, EGME could also induce complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II). However, no similar phenomena are found in other common solvents.
elements.clean_text: Solvent-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation of [Zn4(TIAPy)⋅(DMSO)2⋅(H2O)4]⋅(Guest) (JUC-118) occurs in ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME), caused by the change of the dihedral angle between the pyrene and benzene rings in the ligand. In addition, EGME could also induce complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II). However, no similar phenomena are found in other common solvents.

elements.content: In the past few decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention of chemists all over the world because of their topological architectures and diverse potential uses in many fields such as gas storage, separation, chemical sensors, catalysis, optical, and magnetism. From the structural point of view, most MOFs comprise rigid or soft organic linkers and metal clusters with terminal groups, which are always guest molecules such as water, DMF, methanol, DMSO, and so on. Eliminating or exchanging these terminal groups can often lead to a structure change of the framework. In some cases, the guest-induced structural transformations can induce a sensory response if they also possess properties such as fluorescence or magnetism. A detailed understanding of their structural transformation is of great importance for designing and synthesizing future materials for the applications outlined.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past few decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention of chemists all over the world because of their topological architectures and diverse potential uses in many fields such as gas storage, separation, chemical sensors, catalysis, optical, and magnetism. From the structural point of view, most MOFs comprise rigid or soft organic linkers and metal clusters with terminal groups, which are always guest molecules such as water, DMF, methanol, DMSO, and so on. Eliminating or exchanging these terminal groups can often lead to a structure change of the framework. In some cases, the guest-induced structural transformations can induce a sensory response if they also possess properties such as fluorescence or magnetism. A detailed understanding of their structural transformation is of great importance for designing and synthesizing future materials for the applications outlined.

elements.content: Of all the cases of guest-induced structure transformation, the most common are the change in coordination number or geometry at the metal centers within MOFs by getting rid of the terminal guest molecules by means of heating in a vacuum, which can lead to a dimensionality change. A few reports have demonstrated that as the terminal water molecules of the inorganic cluster are eliminated the inorganic clusters get changed from a mono- or dinuclear to a multinuclear one.
elements.clean_text: Of all the cases of guest-induced structure transformation, the most common are the change in coordination number or geometry at the metal centers within MOFs by getting rid of the terminal guest molecules by means of heating in a vacuum, which can lead to a dimensionality change. A few reports have demonstrated that as the terminal water molecules of the inorganic cluster are eliminated the inorganic clusters get changed from a mono- or dinuclear to a multinuclear one.

elements.content: Another case of guest-responsive behavior is that the structure of MOFs can be induced by the rotating of the relatively rigid organic ligand components. In many rigid MOFs, the organic linkers could act as freely rotating molecular rotors. As they rotate by temperature, pressure, or the presence of specific guests, the channel structure can be affected. Benzene, naphthalene, anthracene, carbazole, and other rigid organic molecules are frequently used to synthesize ligands for MOFs construction; however, the pyrene-based ligand is really rare. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one example, tetrakis­(p-benzoic acid)­pyrene (TBAPy), which was first reported by Rosseinsky et al. in the year of 2010. Till now, the quantity of reports of MOFs constructed with this ligand is only four. Because of the inherent poor solubility, designing and synthesizing a new pyrene-based MOF is a great challenge.
elements.clean_text: Another case of guest-responsive behavior is that the structure of MOFs can be induced by the rotating of the relatively rigid organic ligand components. In many rigid MOFs, the organic linkers could act as freely rotating molecular rotors. As they rotate by temperature, pressure, or the presence of specific guests, the channel structure can be affected. Benzene, naphthalene, anthracene, carbazole, and other rigid organic molecules are frequently used to synthesize ligands for MOFs construction; however, the pyrene-based ligand is really rare. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one example, tetrakis(p-benzoic acid)pyrene (TBAPy), which was first reported by Rosseinsky et al. in the year of 2010. Till now, the quantity of reports of MOFs constructed with this ligand is only four. Because of the inherent poor solubility, designing and synthesizing a new pyrene-based MOF is a great challenge.

elements.content: Besides, metal exchange within MOFs has attracted much attention of crystal engineers because incorporating different metals in the same framework may lead to MOFs with novel or multiple functions. Through metal exchange, new MOFs that cannot be synthesized under conventional conditions may be easily obtained with a good yield. However, metal exchange in porous MOFs are still rare, and the samples of metal exchange are less than 20. This is likely due to the difficulty of cleavage and formation bonds simultaneously occurring in more than one direction and retainment of crystallinity at the same time. Long and Dinca presented one of the first reports on a successful metal exchange in a MOF structure in which colorless MnMOF changed into colorful MII MOFs (MII = Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+) which was mainly induced by simple charge balancing. Almost at the same time, Hou et al. observed partial exchange in a single crystal-to-single crystal fashion in a CdMOF in which the metal exchange for Cu2+ and Pb2+ was driven by the inherent chemical and physical sorption. Among these reports, metal exchange occurring in a specific solvent is rare.
elements.clean_text: Besides, metal exchange within MOFs has attracted much attention of crystal engineers because incorporating different metals in the same framework may lead to MOFs with novel or multiple functions. Through metal exchange, new MOFs that cannot be synthesized under conventional conditions may be easily obtained with a good yield. However, metal exchange in porous MOFs are still rare, and the samples of metal exchange are less than 20. This is likely due to the difficulty of cleavage and formation bonds simultaneously occurring in more than one direction and retainment of crystallinity at the same time. Long and Dinca presented one of the first reports on a successful metal exchange in a MOF structure in which colorless MnMOF changed into colorful MII MOFs (MII = Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+) which was mainly induced by simple charge balancing. Almost at the same time, Hou et al. observed partial exchange in a single crystal-to-single crystal fashion in a CdMOF in which the metal exchange for Cu2+ and Pb2+ was driven by the inherent chemical and physical sorption. Among these reports, metal exchange occurring in a specific solvent is rare.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis of a new pyrene-based ligand 1,3,6,8-tetrakis­(3,5-isophthalic acid)­pyrene (H 8 TIAPy) and a luminescent MOF JUC-118 with squashed channels based on this ligand. Interestingly, the structure of JUC-118 can be induced into another MOF JUC-118-1 with expanded rhombic channels only by the solvent ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME), which is revealed by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Theoretical calculations indicate the low energy barrier of the rotation of δ bonds between the pyrene and benzene rings of the ligand in EGME instead of DMF. In addition, EGME could also induce an almost complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II) in both JUC-118 and JUC-118-1. However, no similar phenomena are found in DMF, DMA, MeOH, DMSO, and other common solvents. This single crystal to single crystal transformation also causes an obvious blue-shift fluorescence emission of the crystals.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis of a new pyrene-based ligand 1,3,6,8-tetrakis(3,5-isophthalic acid)pyrene (H  8  TIAPy) and a luminescent MOF JUC-118 with squashed channels based on this ligand. Interestingly, the structure of JUC-118 can be induced into another MOF JUC-118-1 with expanded rhombic channels only by the solvent ethylene glycol monomethylether (EGME), which is revealed by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Theoretical calculations indicate the low energy barrier of the rotation of δ bonds between the pyrene and benzene rings of the ligand in EGME instead of DMF. In addition, EGME could also induce an almost complete metal exchange of Cu(II) for Zn(II) in both JUC-118 and JUC-118-1. However, no similar phenomena are found in DMF, DMA, MeOH, DMSO, and other common solvents. This single crystal to single crystal transformation also causes an obvious blue-shift fluorescence emission of the crystals.

elements.content: The ligand H 8 TIAPy (Scheme ) was synthesized by a simple Suzuki coupling reaction (). The reaction of H 8 TIAPy with Zn(NO3)2 in an acidic solvent mixture of DMF/DMSO = 5:1 at 85 °C for about 2 days gave the yellow block crystals of JUC-118 formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)­·(DMSO)2­·(H2O)4]­·(Guest) with a good yield. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that JUC-118 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21 /c with the lattice parameters a = 11.078 Å, b = 16.012 Å, c = 23.804 Å, β = 95.333°. There are two unique Zn atoms in the asymmetric units. One is four coordinated and the other is six coordinated. The two Zn atoms are coordinated by three carboxylate groups to form a paddle wheel inorganic cluster, which is not very common in MOF structures. The last site of 4-coordinated Zn and two of the rest of three sites of 6-coordinated Zn are taken over by O atoms from carboxyl groups. One DMSO molecule occupies the only site of the 6-coordinated Zn atom (Figure a). Of all the eight carboxyl groups of the ligand, six of them take a bidentate style with two Zn atoms, and the other two take a monodenetate mode just with one Zn atom (Figure b). Each H 8 TIAPy ligand is coordinated to 14 Zn atoms to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (Figure c). The solvent accessible pore volume of the framework is 61.8% calculated by PLATON. The channel interiors in JUC-118 contained crystallographically disordered solvent molecules that show no indication of preferred location, and attempts for locating them failed. The topology analysis of the framework was conducted by the TOPOS 4.0 program. The dinuclear inorganic cluster could be considered as a four-connected node, and the ligand be an eight-connected one. Thus, the whole framework of JUC-118 could be simplified as a 4,8-net (Figure d) with the topology alb-4,8-P21/c, which is a subnet of alb according to TOPOS analysis. The point symbol for net is {410·614·84}·{45·6}2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characterization

The ligand H  8  TIAPy (Scheme ) was synthesized by a simple Suzuki coupling reaction (). The reaction of H  8  TIAPy with Zn(NO3)2 in an acidic solvent mixture of DMF/DMSO = 5:1 at 85 °C for about 2 days gave the yellow block crystals of JUC-118 formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)⋅(DMSO)2⋅(H2O)4]⋅(Guest) with a good yield. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that JUC-118 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21 /c with the lattice parameters a = 11.078 Å, b = 16.012 Å, c = 23.804 Å, β = 95.333°. There are two unique Zn atoms in the asymmetric units. One is four coordinated and the other is six coordinated. The two Zn atoms are coordinated by three carboxylate groups to form a paddle wheel inorganic cluster, which is not very common in MOF structures. The last site of 4-coordinated Zn and two of the rest of three sites of 6-coordinated Zn are taken over by O atoms from carboxyl groups. One DMSO molecule occupies the only site of the 6-coordinated Zn atom (Figure a). Of all the eight carboxyl groups of the ligand, six of them take a bidentate style with two Zn atoms, and the other two take a monodenetate mode just with one Zn atom (Figure b). Each H  8  TIAPy ligand is coordinated to 14 Zn atoms to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (Figure c). The solvent accessible pore volume of the framework is 61.8% calculated by PLATON. The channel interiors in JUC-118 contained crystallographically disordered solvent molecules that show no indication of preferred location, and attempts for locating them failed. The topology analysis of the framework was conducted by the TOPOS 4.0 program. The dinuclear inorganic cluster could be considered as a four-connected node, and the ligand be an eight-connected one. Thus, the whole framework of JUC-118 could be simplified as a 4,8-net (Figure d) with the topology alb-4,8-P21/c, which is a subnet of alb according to TOPOS analysis. The point symbol for net is {410⋅614⋅84}⋅{45⋅6}2.

elements.content: Solvent-induced crystal transformation experiments were conducted at room temperature by soaking the crystals of JUC-118 in EGME. The transformation was very fast, and the complete transformation took about 3 days. During the process of crystal transformation, the solvent had an obvious blue fluorescence emission under the UV lamp. The fluorescence measurement revealed that the maximum emission was at 464 nm, which was the same with the maximum emission when pure H 8 TIAPy was dissolved in EGME (Figure ). This results may suggest that the Zn–O bonds could be broken during the process of the crystal transformation, and a bit of the ligand was dissolved in the solvent. However, no similar phenomena were found in other common solvents such as DMA, MeOH, MeCN, acetone, and DMSO (). The detailed mechanism will be discussed in the following section.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Transformation

Solvent-induced crystal transformation experiments were conducted at room temperature by soaking the crystals of JUC-118 in EGME. The transformation was very fast, and the complete transformation took about 3 days. During the process of crystal transformation, the solvent had an obvious blue fluorescence emission under the UV lamp. The fluorescence measurement revealed that the maximum emission was at 464 nm, which was the same with the maximum emission when pure H  8  TIAPy was dissolved in EGME (Figure ). This results may suggest that the Zn-O bonds could be broken during the process of the crystal transformation, and a bit of the ligand was dissolved in the solvent. However, no similar phenomena were found in other common solvents such as DMA, MeOH, MeCN, acetone, and DMSO (). The detailed mechanism will be discussed in the following section.

elements.content: The fluorescence emisson for the solvent of EGME after soaking JUC-118(red line) and dissolving pure H 8 TIAPy (black line). The photo at the top-right corner is JUC-118 soaking in DMF and EGME under a UV lamp. Clearly, the solvent EGME had a bright blue emission compared to DMF, which was nonemitting.
elements.clean_text: 2  The fluorescence emisson for the solvent of EGME after soaking JUC-118(red line) and dissolving pure H  8  TIAPy (black line). The photo at the top-right corner is JUC-118 soaking in DMF and EGME under a UV lamp. Clearly, the solvent EGME had a bright blue emission compared to DMF, which was nonemitting.

elements.content: The new crystal obtained after the transformation is named as JUC-118-1, which can be formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)­·(H2O)4­·(EGME)2]­·(Guest) by single crystal diffraction and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) indicated the complete transformation (Figure ). Obvious differences can be found between the PXRD patterns of JUC-118 and JUC-118-1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the lattice parameters of JUC-118-1 had obviously changed to be a = 12.314 Å, b = 14.986 Å, c = 26.349 Å, β = 99.817° in P21 /c. As the lattice parameters changed, the channel structure along the [101] direction changed accordingly, from a narrow compressed rhombic shape in JUC-118 to an expanded one in JUC-118-1, which was just like the breathing behavior of MIL-53.
elements.clean_text: The new crystal obtained after the transformation is named as JUC-118-1, which can be formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)⋅(H2O)4⋅(EGME)2]⋅(Guest) by single crystal diffraction and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) indicated the complete transformation (Figure ). Obvious differences can be found between the PXRD patterns of JUC-118 and JUC-118-1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the lattice parameters of JUC-118-1 had obviously changed to be a = 12.314 Å, b = 14.986 Å, c = 26.349 Å, β = 99.817° in P21 /c. As the lattice parameters changed, the channel structure along the [101] direction changed accordingly, from a narrow compressed rhombic shape in JUC-118 to an expanded one in JUC-118-1, which was just like the breathing behavior of MIL-53.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of (a) calculated from JUC-118-1, (b) as-synthesized sample of JUC-118-1, (c) calculated from JUC-118.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD patterns of (a) calculated from JUC-118-1, (b) as-synthesized sample of JUC-118-1, (c) calculated from JUC-118.

elements.content: To study their structure transformation, we observed that the exact torsion angles between the pyrene and the benzene rings of the ligand have changed, which leads to the whole structure transformation. Of all the four torsion angles in the ligand, only two of them had changed. In the crystal of JUC-118, they were 41.165(2) deg; however, they became 61.255(1) deg in the JUC-118-1. Thus, the channels were also obviously changed, from 16.2 × 7.4 Å2 in JUC-118 to 15.5 × 8.8 Å2 in JUC-118-1 (Figure ). The corresponding solvent accessible volumes for JUC-118 and JUC-118-1 were calculated to be 61.8% and 66.8% respectively by the PLATON analysis.
elements.clean_text: To study their structure transformation, we observed that the exact torsion angles between the pyrene and the benzene rings of the ligand have changed, which leads to the whole structure transformation. Of all the four torsion angles in the ligand, only two of them had changed. In the crystal of JUC-118, they were 41.165(2) deg; however, they became 61.255(1) deg in the JUC-118-1. Thus, the channels were also obviously changed, from 16.2 × 7.4 Å2 in JUC-118 to 15.5 × 8.8 Å2 in JUC-118-1 (Figure ). The corresponding solvent accessible volumes for JUC-118 and JUC-118-1 were calculated to be 61.8% and 66.8% respectively by the PLATON analysis.

elements.content: (a) The compressed rhombic channel of JUC-118; (b) the expanded rhombic channel of JUC-118-1; (c) the torsion angle between the pyrene and the benzene ring in JUC-118; (d) the torsion angle in JUC-118-1; (e) the pore size of JUC-118; (f) the pore size of JUC-118-1.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The compressed rhombic channel of JUC-118; (b) the expanded rhombic channel of JUC-118-1; (c) the torsion angle between the pyrene and the benzene ring in JUC-118; (d) the torsion angle in JUC-118-1; (e) the pore size of JUC-118; (f) the pore size of JUC-118-1.

elements.content: The solvent-induced metal exchange phenomenon was discovered by soaking the only one quality crystal of JUC-118 in a solution of Cu(NO3)2 in EGME. The crystal gradually turned green, and the metal exchange was finished 3 days later. The green crystal was named JUC-118-Cu (Figure ). An ICP test for the JUC-118-Cu demonstrated that the Cu content in the JUC-118-Cu was 98.8%, which meant the Zn atoms in JUC-118 were almost completely exchanged. Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement suggested that JUC-118-Cu had the identical structure with JUC-118-1. It is worth mentioning that JUC-118-1 can also be used to obtain JUC-118-Cu via a similar soaking process. However, the metal exchange could not occur in DMF, DMA, acetone, MeOH, MeCN, and DMSO even though JUC-118-1 was used for the metal exchange experiments (Figure ). This result indicated that EGME was necessary for the metal exchange process just like the structural transformation process. In addition, JUC-118-Cu could no longer convert back to JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 either in DMF or in EGME. To test the reversibility of the metal exchange process, we had soaked one quality crystal of JUC-118-Cu in the solution of Zn(NO3)2 in EGME (or DMF separately). It was found that the green crystal could no longer turned yellow, which meant the irreversible transformation. These results indicate that JUC-118-Cu was more stable.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent-Induced Metal Exchange

The solvent-induced metal exchange phenomenon was discovered by soaking the only one quality crystal of JUC-118 in a solution of Cu(NO3)2 in EGME. The crystal gradually turned green, and the metal exchange was finished 3 days later. The green crystal was named JUC-118-Cu (Figure ). An ICP test for the JUC-118-Cu demonstrated that the Cu content in the JUC-118-Cu was 98.8%, which meant the Zn atoms in JUC-118 were almost completely exchanged. Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement suggested that JUC-118-Cu had the identical structure with JUC-118-1. It is worth mentioning that JUC-118-1 can also be used to obtain JUC-118-Cu via a similar soaking process. However, the metal exchange could not occur in DMF, DMA, acetone, MeOH, MeCN, and DMSO even though JUC-118-1 was used for the metal exchange experiments (Figure ). This result indicated that EGME was necessary for the metal exchange process just like the structural transformation process. In addition, JUC-118-Cu could no longer convert back to JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 either in DMF or in EGME. To test the reversibility of the metal exchange process, we had soaked one quality crystal of JUC-118-Cu in the solution of Zn(NO3)2 in EGME (or DMF separately). It was found that the green crystal could no longer turned yellow, which meant the irreversible transformation. These results indicate that JUC-118-Cu was more stable.

elements.content: Photos of the crystal before (left, yellow JUC-118) and after (right, green JUC-118-Cu) transformation.
elements.clean_text: 5  Photos of the crystal before (left, yellow JUC-118) and after (right, green JUC-118-Cu) transformation.

elements.content: The chart of mutual conversion relations among JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu.
elements.clean_text: 6  The chart of mutual conversion relations among JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) was used to calculate the rotation barrier for the benzene rings in TIAPy 8‑ when soaking JUC-118 in DMF and EGMG, respectively. Calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 program on the platform of Ubuntu. The basis set was chosen to be 6-31G(d), and the DFT function was B3LYP. Spin-restricted Kohn–Sham determinants were chosen to describe the close-shell wave functions. The solvation model was IEFPCM. Potential energy surfaces were constructed by fixing the Cartesian coordinates of pyrene ring and varying one Cpy–Cpy–Cph–Cph (Cpy meant C atom of the pyrene and Cpy meant C atom of the benzene ring) dihedral angle, while the remaining coordinates were allowed to relax. The potential energies of the ligand were determined in both DMF and EGME, and the difference was compared. It was found that the torsional energy barrier of TIAPy 8‑ in EGME was about 8 kJ/mol and 4 kJ/mol lower than that in DMF (Figure ). As the energy barrier was lower in EGME, the benzene rings were easier to rotate to take a more stable conformation, in favor of crystal transformation.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculation

Density functional theory (DFT) was used to calculate the rotation barrier for the benzene rings in TIAPy  8-  when soaking JUC-118 in DMF and EGMG, respectively. Calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 program on the platform of Ubuntu. The basis set was chosen to be 6-31G(d), and the DFT function was B3LYP. Spin-restricted Kohn-Sham determinants were chosen to describe the close-shell wave functions. The solvation model was IEFPCM. Potential energy surfaces were constructed by fixing the Cartesian coordinates of pyrene ring and varying one Cpy-Cpy-Cph-Cph (Cpy meant C atom of the pyrene and Cpy meant C atom of the benzene ring) dihedral angle, while the remaining coordinates were allowed to relax. The potential energies of the ligand were determined in both DMF and EGME, and the difference was compared. It was found that the torsional energy barrier of TIAPy  8-  in EGME was about 8 kJ/mol and 4 kJ/mol lower than that in DMF (Figure ). As the energy barrier was lower in EGME, the benzene rings were easier to rotate to take a more stable conformation, in favor of crystal transformation.

elements.content: DFT-calculated torsional barrier in TIAPy 8‑ with the coordinates of pyrene fixed. The potential energy surfaces were scanned by 5° a time and 200° totally.
elements.clean_text: 7  DFT-calculated torsional barrier in TIAPy  8-  with the coordinates of pyrene fixed. The potential energy surfaces were scanned by 5° a time and 200° totally.

elements.content: On the basis of the experimental and theoretical results, the mechanism could be disscussed here. When the crystals of JUC-118 were soaked in EGME at first, the EGME molecules would attack the dinuclear cluster and break the Zn–O bonds in JUC-118 as a chemical breaker, which could also explain the fluorescence emission of the EGME solution under the UV-lamp when JUC-118 was soaked in the solution for a while. The rotation of the benzene rings of the ligand would be easier in EGME than DMF verified by theoretical calculations. In other words, DMF restricts the rotation of benzene ring and restrains the ligand from being in its conformation with minimum energy. The Zn–O (or Cu–O in JUC-118-Cu) would be generated when there were Zn2+ (or Cu2+) and the ligand in the solution, and the structure of JUC-118-1 (or JUC-118-Cu) with higher stability would be formed. The irreversible conversion from JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 to JUC-118-Cu indicated that these crystal transformation processes were dynamically favorable.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the experimental and theoretical results, the mechanism could be disscussed here. When the crystals of JUC-118 were soaked in EGME at first, the EGME molecules would attack the dinuclear cluster and break the Zn-O bonds in JUC-118 as a chemical breaker, which could also explain the fluorescence emission of the EGME solution under the UV-lamp when JUC-118 was soaked in the solution for a while. The rotation of the benzene rings of the ligand would be easier in EGME than DMF verified by theoretical calculations. In other words, DMF restricts the rotation of benzene ring and restrains the ligand from being in its conformation with minimum energy. The Zn-O (or Cu-O in JUC-118-Cu) would be generated when there were Zn2+ (or Cu2+) and the ligand in the solution, and the structure of JUC-118-1 (or JUC-118-Cu) with higher stability would be formed. The irreversible conversion from JUC-118 or JUC-118-1 to JUC-118-Cu indicated that these crystal transformation processes were dynamically favorable.

elements.content: The fluorescence properties of both JUC-118 and JUC-118-1 were measured by FLUOROMAX-4 spectrometer. The maximum fluorescence emission of the ligand and JUC-118 was at 539 and 485 nm, respectively (Figure ). JUC-118 had a 54 nm blue shift compared to the ligand. After crystal transformation, the maximum emission of JUC-118-1 was at 460 nm, a blue shift of 25 nm compared to JUC-118. This blue shift could be attributed to the structural changes induced by EGME. After crystal transformation, the dihedral angle of the pyrene and benzene rings changed from 41.2 deg in JUC-118 to 61.3 deg in JUC-118-1 causing the conjugacy of the ligand to get poorer; thus the HOMO–LUMO gap got larger, and the maximum fluorescence emission had an obvious blue shift.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The fluorescence properties of both JUC-118 and JUC-118-1 were measured by FLUOROMAX-4 spectrometer. The maximum fluorescence emission of the ligand and JUC-118 was at 539 and 485 nm, respectively (Figure ). JUC-118 had a 54 nm blue shift compared to the ligand. After crystal transformation, the maximum emission of JUC-118-1 was at 460 nm, a blue shift of 25 nm compared to JUC-118. This blue shift could be attributed to the structural changes induced by EGME. After crystal transformation, the dihedral angle of the pyrene and benzene rings changed from 41.2 deg in JUC-118 to 61.3 deg in JUC-118-1 causing the conjugacy of the ligand to get poorer; thus the HOMO-LUMO gap got larger, and the maximum fluorescence emission had an obvious blue shift.

elements.content: Fluorescence emission spectra of (a) the ligand, (b) JUC-118, and (c) JUC-118-1 collected in the solid state at room temperature. The maximum emissions for them were 539, 485, and 460 nm, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 8  Fluorescence emission spectra of (a) the ligand, (b) JUC-118, and (c) JUC-118-1 collected in the solid state at room temperature. The maximum emissions for them were 539, 485, and 460 nm, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, a pyrene-based MOF JUC-118 was synthesized, and the solvent-induced crystal transformation from single crystal to single crystal of JUC-118 was investigated. After a detail study, it is revealed that the changed crystal parameters were caused by the change of the torsion angles between the pyrene and the benzene rings of the ligand. The crystal transformation is only found in EGME. Theoretical calculation demonstrates that EGME could decrease the energy barrier of the rotation of the benzene rings of the ligand effectively, which would lead to the crystal transformation. In addition, when soaking the crystals in EGME dissolving Cu(NO3)2, a complete metal exchange for Cu occurs gradually confirmed by an ICP test. The bright blue fluorescence under a UV lamp of EGME solution with JUC-118 should indicate the breaking of the Zn–O bonds and a bit of ligand dissolved in the solution during crystal transformation. This understanding for the solvent-induced structural transformation from this study might guide us to design and synthesis novel materials for the applications in guest recognization and detection.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a pyrene-based MOF JUC-118 was synthesized, and the solvent-induced crystal transformation from single crystal to single crystal of JUC-118 was investigated. After a detail study, it is revealed that the changed crystal parameters were caused by the change of the torsion angles between the pyrene and the benzene rings of the ligand. The crystal transformation is only found in EGME. Theoretical calculation demonstrates that EGME could decrease the energy barrier of the rotation of the benzene rings of the ligand effectively, which would lead to the crystal transformation. In addition, when soaking the crystals in EGME dissolving Cu(NO3)2, a complete metal exchange for Cu occurs gradually confirmed by an ICP test. The bright blue fluorescence under a UV lamp of EGME solution with JUC-118 should indicate the breaking of the Zn-O bonds and a bit of ligand dissolved in the solution during crystal transformation. This understanding for the solvent-induced structural transformation from this study might guide us to design and synthesis novel materials for the applications in guest recognization and detection.

elements.content: Pyrene and Pd(PPh3)4 were bought from Sigma-Aldrich. The detail synthesis processes of the ligand H 8 TIAPy are listed in . Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku DMAX 2550 diffractometer at 50 kV, 20 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Pekin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 5 °C per minute. Fluorescence measurement was performed on FLUOROMAX-4 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Pyrene and Pd(PPh3)4 were bought from Sigma-Aldrich. The detail synthesis processes of the ligand H  8  TIAPy are listed in . Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku DMAX 2550 diffractometer at 50 kV, 20 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Pekin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 5 °C per minute. Fluorescence measurement was performed on FLUOROMAX-4 spectrometer.

elements.content: H 8 TIAPy (5 mg, 0.0058 mmol), Zn(NO3)2 (10 mg, 0.0529 mmol), DMF (5 mL), DMSO (1 mL), and 2 M HNO3 (0.8 mL) were combined in a 20 mL glass vial, sealed and heated to 85 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block crystals were collected and air-dried (yield: 80% based on H 8 TIAPy). Elemental analysis for Zn4(TIAPy)­(DMSO)2­(H2O)4 = C52H38O22Zn4, calculated (%): C, 48.98; H, 2.98; O, 27.63; Zn, 20.41. Found (%): C, 48.75; H, 3.04; O, 27.91; Zn, 20.31.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of JUC-118 

 H  8  TIAPy (5 mg, 0.0058 mmol), Zn(NO3)2 (10 mg, 0.0529 mmol), DMF (5 mL), DMSO (1 mL), and 2 M HNO3 (0.8 mL) were combined in a 20 mL glass vial, sealed and heated to 85 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block crystals were collected and air-dried (yield: 80% based on H  8  TIAPy). Elemental analysis for Zn4(TIAPy)(DMSO)2(H2O)4 = C52H38O22Zn4, calculated (%): C, 48.98; H, 2.98; O, 27.63; Zn, 20.41. Found (%): C, 48.75; H, 3.04; O, 27.91; Zn, 20.31.

elements.content: Single Crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected using a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX2 CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ= 0.71073 Å). Indexing was performed using APEX2 (Difference Vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus. Absorption correction was performed by multiscan method implemented in SADABS. Space groups were determined using XPREP implemented in APEX2. Structures were solved using SHELXL-97 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-97 (full-matrix least-squares on F2) with anisotropic displacement contained in APEX2 program packages. Hydrogen atoms on carbon and nitrogen were calculated in ideal positions with isotropic placement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atoms, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not added into the structure. In the structure, free solvent molecules were highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were not successful. Contributions to scattering due to these solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON, and the structures were then refined again using the data generated. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in the crystal data. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu are summarized in Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Single Crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected using a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX2 CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ= 0.71073 Å). Indexing was performed using APEX2 (Difference Vectors method). Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus. Absorption correction was performed by multiscan method implemented in SADABS. Space groups were determined using XPREP implemented in APEX2. Structures were solved using SHELXL-97 (direct methods) and refined using SHELXL-97 (full-matrix least-squares on F2) with anisotropic displacement contained in APEX2 program packages. Hydrogen atoms on carbon and nitrogen were calculated in ideal positions with isotropic placement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atoms, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not added into the structure. In the structure, free solvent molecules were highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were not successful. Contributions to scattering due to these solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON, and the structures were then refined again using the data generated. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in the crystal data. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu are summarized in Table S1 ().

elements.content: Detailed synthesis method of H 8 TIAPy, crystal structure representation of JUC-118, PXRD, UV–vis spectra, TGA and fluorescence spectra of JUC-118 and JUC-118-1, crystal structure data and CIF files of JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu. The supplementary crystallographic datas for this paper were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) as entry CCDC 971756–971758.This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Detailed synthesis method of H  8  TIAPy, crystal structure representation of JUC-118, PXRD, UV-vis spectra, TGA and fluorescence spectra of JUC-118 and JUC-118-1, crystal structure data and CIF files of JUC-118, JUC-118-1, and JUC-118-Cu. The supplementary crystallographic datas for this paper were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) as entry CCDC 971756-971758.This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of JUC-118 

 H  8  TIAPy (5 mg, 0.0058 mmol), Zn(NO3)2 (10 mg, 0.0529 mmol), DMF (5 mL), DMSO (1 mL), and 2 M HNO3 (0.8 mL) were combined in a 20 mL glass vial, sealed and heated to 85 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow block crystals were collected and air-dried (yield: 80% based on H  8  TIAPy). Elemental analysis for Zn4(TIAPy)(DMSO)2(H2O)4 = C52H38O22Zn4, calculated (%): C, 48.98; H, 2.98; O, 27.63; Zn, 20.41. Found (%): C, 48.75; H, 3.04; O, 27.91; Zn, 20.31.

cln_elements.content: The ligand H 8 TIAPy (Scheme ) was synthesized by a simple Suzuki coupling reaction (). The reaction of H 8 TIAPy with Zn(NO3)2 in an acidic solvent mixture of DMF/DMSO = 5:1 at 85 °C for about 2 days gave the yellow block crystals of JUC-118 formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)­·(DMSO)2­·(H2O)4]­·(Guest) with a good yield. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that JUC-118 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21 /c with the lattice parameters a = 11.078 Å, b = 16.012 Å, c = 23.804 Å, β = 95.333°. There are two unique Zn atoms in the asymmetric units. One is four coordinated and the other is six coordinated. The two Zn atoms are coordinated by three carboxylate groups to form a paddle wheel inorganic cluster, which is not very common in MOF structures. The last site of 4-coordinated Zn and two of the rest of three sites of 6-coordinated Zn are taken over by O atoms from carboxyl groups. One DMSO molecule occupies the only site of the 6-coordinated Zn atom (Figure a). Of all the eight carboxyl groups of the ligand, six of them take a bidentate style with two Zn atoms, and the other two take a monodenetate mode just with one Zn atom (Figure b). Each H 8 TIAPy ligand is coordinated to 14 Zn atoms to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (Figure c). The solvent accessible pore volume of the framework is 61.8% calculated by PLATON. The channel interiors in JUC-118 contained crystallographically disordered solvent molecules that show no indication of preferred location, and attempts for locating them failed. The topology analysis of the framework was conducted by the TOPOS 4.0 program. The dinuclear inorganic cluster could be considered as a four-connected node, and the ligand be an eight-connected one. Thus, the whole framework of JUC-118 could be simplified as a 4,8-net (Figure d) with the topology alb-4,8-P21/c, which is a subnet of alb according to TOPOS analysis. The point symbol for net is {410·614·84}·{45·6}2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characterization

The ligand H  8  TIAPy (Scheme ) was synthesized by a simple Suzuki coupling reaction (). The reaction of H  8  TIAPy with Zn(NO3)2 in an acidic solvent mixture of DMF/DMSO = 5:1 at 85 °C for about 2 days gave the yellow block crystals of JUC-118 formulated as [Zn4(TIAPy)⋅(DMSO)2⋅(H2O)4]⋅(Guest) with a good yield. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that JUC-118 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21 /c with the lattice parameters a = 11.078 Å, b = 16.012 Å, c = 23.804 Å, β = 95.333°. There are two unique Zn atoms in the asymmetric units. One is four coordinated and the other is six coordinated. The two Zn atoms are coordinated by three carboxylate groups to form a paddle wheel inorganic cluster, which is not very common in MOF structures. The last site of 4-coordinated Zn and two of the rest of three sites of 6-coordinated Zn are taken over by O atoms from carboxyl groups. One DMSO molecule occupies the only site of the 6-coordinated Zn atom (Figure a). Of all the eight carboxyl groups of the ligand, six of them take a bidentate style with two Zn atoms, and the other two take a monodenetate mode just with one Zn atom (Figure b). Each H  8  TIAPy ligand is coordinated to 14 Zn atoms to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (Figure c). The solvent accessible pore volume of the framework is 61.8% calculated by PLATON. The channel interiors in JUC-118 contained crystallographically disordered solvent molecules that show no indication of preferred location, and attempts for locating them failed. The topology analysis of the framework was conducted by the TOPOS 4.0 program. The dinuclear inorganic cluster could be considered as a four-connected node, and the ligand be an eight-connected one. Thus, the whole framework of JUC-118 could be simplified as a 4,8-net (Figure d) with the topology alb-4,8-P21/c, which is a subnet of alb according to TOPOS analysis. The point symbol for net is {410⋅614⋅84}⋅{45⋅6}2.

metadata.title:
Solvent-Induced Single Crystal To Single Crystal Transformation
and Complete Metal Exchange of a Pyrene-Based Metal–Organic
Framework
